awd_titl_txt: Crystallographically-oriented Lamellae Phases in Garnet and Their Potential Use as Petrogenetic Indicators, Central Maine Terrane, Connecticut
awd_abstract_narration:
Tectonic plates are consumed at subduction zones, vast undersea regions which stretch thousands of miles across the face of our planet. During subduction, one plate sinks beneath another to be recycled into Earth's mantle. Subduction zones are the sites of active volcanism, the largest known earthquakes, and a wide array of mineral deposit types. Tracing the history of subduction as recorded in mountain belts is essential for reconstructing plate movements, paleogeography, paleobiology, and paleoclimate throughout geologic time. The Appalachian-Caledonide mountain chain is one of the largest in the world, stretching from the southern and eastern United States up through Canada and Greenland and across to Europe. Nonetheless, the record of subduction in the northeastern United States is surprisingly cryptic in terms of the rock record it left behind, particularly in terms of the metamorphic rocks comprising the deep roots of the mountain belt. New discoveries, however, are providing fresh perspectives, including the recognition of "ultrahigh-temperature" metamorphic rocks in northeastern Connecticut (CT) formed in excess of 900 °C (about 1650 °F). Of major significance is that this CT locality also preserves tantalizing evidence for subduction of crust to great depths-perhaps in excess of 60-100 miles. The research project will focus on these CT rocks as they may be the first "ultrahigh-pressure" (UHP) metamorphic rocks definitively recognized in the United States; their presence would catalyze a rethinking of how, where, and why rocks were subducted during Appalachian mountain building. More broadly, a deeper understanding of the tectonic architecture of the region may help resolve longstanding questions involving Paleozoic plate movement and associated implications for the location and geologic formation of natural resources in the mountain belt (which extends into the Arctic and potentially as far west as Alaska). The project will support and train Yale Ph.D. and undergraduate students, and integrate research results into public science outreach programs at the Yale Peabody Museum of Natural History. 

Gneisses in the field area host garnets that contain spectacular examples of crystallographically-oriented lamellae minerals (rutile, ilmenite, apatite, amphibole, pyroxene, quartz, and other phases). Comparisons with other localities worldwide indicate that such lamellae correlate broadly with pressure-temperature conditions and, thus, they hold considerable but as yet mostly untapped potential as petrogenetic indicators. For example, lamellae assemblages including rutile, ilmenite, quartz, amphibole, and apatite are documented only from UHP settings. In order to be used to diagnose metamorphic regimes, however, lamellae origins must be understood. Consequently, this project will undertake mineralogical and petrological study of the lamellae in the CT garnets involving: (1) Characterization of lamellae assemblages and chemical compositions via electron imaging and microprobe techniques together with Raman spectroscopy. (2) Electron-backscatter diffraction and transmission electron microscopy studies to determine crystallographic relationships between garnet and lamellae. (3) Chemical mapping using the electron microprobe to image closed and open-system garnet behavior. (4) Field work to identify other lamellae-bearing garnet localities in the region. The results of the above research will be used to test whether or not the lamellae are the products of exsolution from garnet, or if they formed by some other mechanism such as coupled infiltration and precipitation. If the former, then the Si-, Ti-, and P-rich garnet compositions point strongly toward majoritic garnet precursors formed at UHP conditions ~5 GPa or higher during subduction. Regardless of hypothesis test outcomes, lamellae formation processes must be better understood to help guide petrotectonic interpretations in New England and other orogenic belts across the globe.

por.por_cntn:
This project centered on new mineralogical approaches to the study of ultrahigh-temperature and ultrahigh-pressure rocks with broad applications to the study of planetary interiors. The mineral garnet was our primary focus. Garnets that form deep in mountain belts may crystallize at ultrahigh-temperatures (UHT) greater than 900 oC and/or ultrahigh pressures greater than 3 GPa. Garnets that crystallize at these conditions can contain a range of trace elements including titanium and phosphorus. When the garnets cool and decompress as they are brought back to Earth's surface by tectonic forces, these constituents can ?unmix? or ?exsolve? from the garnet to form characteristically oriented precipitates of minerals such as rutile, apatite, ilmenite, and quartz. On the basis of these textures and other geologic relationships, our work has discovered a range of previously unknown UHT and UHP rocks in part of the eroded Acadian mountain belt in northeastern Connecticut. Our major findings can be summarized as follows. First, we documented the first UHT high-pressure granulite metamorphic rocks known in the United States, formed at temperatures in excess of 1000 oC and pressures of at least 1.8 GPa, corresponding to depths below the ancient ground surface of roughly 65 km (~40 miles). These extreme conditions were verified by both field-based and laboratory experimental study, the latter in collaboration with colleagues from the GFZ, Potsdam, Germany (the experimental work was funded independently of this project). Second, we documented the occurrence of UHP rocks in the field area, one of possibly only two from North America. These rocks were formed at truly extreme pressures exceeding 5 GPa, corresponding to depths of 150?200 km below the ancient ground surface. Third, we documented systematic crystallographic orientation relationships (COR) between host garnets and the minerals that ?unmixed? from them. Our approach includes the first mineralogical application of which we are aware of the edge-to-edge matching (E2EM) model developed in materials science. Overall, we were able to successfully predict, for the first time, 88% to 98% of the observed crystallographic alignments between garnet and the unmixed minerals. Fourth, we established that there are a number of previously unappreciated pitfalls in the identification of UHP minerals, including the confusion of the UHP mineral coesite with common rock grinding materials or the mineral xenotime.

In addition to these studies, considerable adjacent work was made possible by the project. For example, we were able to identify the deep igneous roots of the ancient Acadian volcanic mountain chain intermixed with the UHT and UHP rocks described above in a ?m?lange?. This is the first such m?lange discovered in New England of which we are aware. Moreover, the rocks document important processes involving the sequestration of copper at depth which have considerable implications for the nature and global distribution of porphyry copper deposits (the world?s main source of copper). These studies used samples from the project but were funded independently. Finally, the work provided multiple examples that were included in a new edition of a textbook coauthored by the principal investigator.

The overall significance of the work in terms of intellectual merit is two-fold. First, we documented that the oriented minerals in garnet were crystallographically controlled precipitates that provide a window into former garnet chemistry prior to unmixing. As such, they are valuable indicators of rock formation conditions and can be used in mountain belts worldwide to explore for extreme temperature and/or pressure rocks. Second, our work documents deep subduction during the closure of the Iapetus Ocean. Large-scale UHP metamorphism due to the subduction of Baltica beneath North America during these times is well known (e.g., Norway). However, our work in the continuous and coeval New England rocks documents that subduction resulting from microcontinent-continent convergence can also produce UHP conditions, forcing a rethinking of overarching tectonic models for the region.

In terms of broader impacts and human resource development, the project provided partial or complete support for 18 papers published in peer-reviewed journals or presentations at conferences, one Ph.D. thesis, one senior B.S. thesis, postdoctoral work, and one textbook. The project informed the redesign of the Yale Peabody Museum's exhibits on the mineralogy of Connecticut. The museum is currently closed for a complete renovation and is scheduled to reopen in 2023. Our normal public outreach activities were somewhat curtailed due to the COVID-19 pandemic and museum closure, but will return in full in the coming year. Specimens collected for the project are routinely used for teaching in mineralogy and petrology classes offered in our department (Earth and Planetary Sciences). Our work also documents that edge-to-edge matching is a valuable predictive tool to identify and characterize precipitates in silicate-oxide, silicate-phosphate, and silicate-silicate systems. Thus, it may have application to the study of precipitates in ceramics and the precipitation of oxides, silicates, and phosphates in alloys.
